results.title: Hondo
results.creator_credit: John Farrow, Robert Fellows and Wayne-Fellows Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Louis L’Amour, John Wayne’s own favourite movie features the actor in the role of Hondo, a half-Indian cavalry scout. Set in 1874 against the unrest and hostility caused by the white man’s violation of the treaty with the Apache Nation, the plot concerns Hondo’s protection of a young woman and her son whom he discovers living alone in Apache territory. The film extends liberal respect to the Indians and even implicitly endorses the inter-racial romance that develops between the white women and the half-breed Hondo. With impressive cinematography by Robert Burke, the film was restored and re-released by the John Wayne estate in 1995. Cast includes Geraldine Page. Ward Bond and Michael Pate.

results.title: Joan of Arc
results.creator_credit: Victor Fleming, Walter Wanger and Sierra Pictures

Based on the stage play ‘Joan of Lorraine’, by Maxwell Anderson. Cast includes Ingrid Bergman, Jose Ferrer, Ward Bond and Francis L. Sullivan.

results.title: The Left handed gun
results.creator_credit: Arthur Penn, Fred Coe and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Adapted from the play by Gore Vidal, “The Left Handed Gun” is the story of William Bonney, the hotheaded gunslinger known as Billy the Kid. Avoiding the usual Hollywood glamourisation of this controversial character, Paul Newman portrays Billy pretty much as he was: an illiterate, homicidal youth. Treated with kindness for the first time in his life by rancher Tunstall, Billy becomes devoted to the rancher. After Tunstall is killed, however, Billy is prompted to go on a murderous spree avenging the death of his former employer. Cast includes: Paul Newman, James Best, Lita Milan, Hurd Hatfield, and James Congdon.

results.title: The Naked truth = Your past is showing
results.creator_credit: Mario Zampi and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: A satire of the tabloid-press industry, “The Naked Truth” focuses on a scandal-sheet publisher, Nigel Dennis, who gets rich by disclosing lurid details of the private lives of wealthy prominent people. Several of his victims attempt to do away with the blackmailing publisher, all to no avail. But when they all join forces, the final plan is brought into play, with each piece slowly falling into place. Cast includes: Dennis Price, Peter Sellers, Terry-Thomas, Shirley Eaton, Peggy Mount, Georgina Cookson, Joan Sims and Miles Malleson.

results.title: Day of wrath
results.creator_credit: Carl Theodor Dreyer and Palladium Films
results.brief_description: Set in 17th century Europe, “Day of Wrath” is an intense and tragic study of how a young woman is destroyed by the charge of witchcraft. Anne is married to the much older pastor, Absalon Pedersson. She is attracted to her step-son Martin and when Absalon dies of a heart attack, the accusations begin that his death was caused through Anne’s sorcery. Now considered one of the great works of European cinema, “Day of Wrath” is not interested in the occult as much as it explores the psychology of harsh puritanism, especially the debilitating effects of such repression on women. From her initial horror at the accusations, to her remorse and final acceptance, Anne’s story transcends the supernatural and becomes a terrifyingly contemporary study of alienation and emotional betrayal. Based on the play “Anne Pedersdotter” by Wiers Jenssens, Dreyer has reconceived the story and created one of the great feminist works of cinema. Released in Denmark during the Nazi occupation, “Day of Wrath” resonates as a study of terror, hatred and collaboration. With Thorkid Roose, Ilsbeth Movin and Sigrid Neiiendam. In Danish with English subtitles.

results.title: Gone in 60 seconds = Gone in sixty seconds
results.creator_credit: H.B. Halicki, Junk Yard and H B Halicki Mercantile Co
results.brief_description: Sixty seconds is all it takes for professional car thief Maindrian Pace (H.B. Halicki, who also wrote, produced and directed) to steal a car, and he’s in the perfect position to fuel his habit - working for an insurance adjustment firm. With a script boasting real life stunt drivers who also happen to be associates of Halicki, this film features a 40 minute Mustang car chase sequence where it is reported that over 93 cars were destroyed. The film received mixed reviews, however it also received a cult following from those amongst the community who like mustangs, car chases, the seventies and a stunt co-ordinator let loose with a film camera.

results.title: Happiness [Widescreen] (E)
results.creator_credit: Todd Solondz, Christine Vachon, Ted Hope, Killer Films and Good Machine International
results.brief_description: This controversial and darkly funny independent film is an examination of the alienated lives of three middle-class sisters. The eldest (Elizabeth Ashley) believes herself to be happily married and the epitome of suburban success, but she is unaware that her psychiatrist husband lusts after his son’s school-boy friends; the middle sister (Lara Flynn Boyle) is an emotionally sterile successful writer who is fascinated by the obscene phonecalls of her next door neighbour; and the youngest (Jane Adams) is an eternally optimistic hippie who maintains a Candide-like faith in her fellow humans and therefore ends up being taken advantage of by family, friends and colleagues. Populated by a cast of talented character actors, “Happiness” is a sharply scripted film that explores the break-down of family life and community. By focussing on sexual relationships that mainstream English-language cinema usually only presents as evil or extreme, the film also manages to present the underlying loneliness that leads to the bleakness and alienation of modern suburban life. In its final devastating scenes, the film also manages to convey powerfully, and unexpectedly, the importance of familial relationships. Often criticised as cynical, the reality is that in its final moments, “Happiness” reveals itself as a compassionate and moving film. Cast includes Ben Gazzara, Louise Lasser, Phillip Seymour Hoffman and Cynthia Stevenson.

results.title: Girl 6 = Girl six
results.creator_credit: Spike Lee, Fox Searchlight Pictures and 40 Acres and a Mule Filmworks
results.brief_description: Theresa Randle is an attractive and talented actress but her inability to find acting work leads her to get a job working as a sex-phone operator. Initially suspicious, if intrigued, by the agency she works for, she finds that her work leads to her gaining empowerment over herself and her sexuality. Spike Lee’s “Girl 6” stands as one of his most under-rated films. A clear-sighted examination of fantasy, this film features an excellent cast of women who approach their life, work and relationships with street-smart humour. It is the men around them who find themselves ultimately more repressed by the guilt and shame with which they shroud their sexual fantasies. The film also intelligently and sharply explores the contradictions of race and performance, examining how for an African-American woman the “invisibility” of voice and the phone allows for a greater opportunity of expression than when roles are circumscribed by the hue of her skin colour. This is a vibrant, entertaining and poignant film. Features cameo appearances by Madonna, Quentin Tarantino, Debi Mazar, Naomi Campbell and Halle Berry.
